programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Howard has a suggestion for Emma, while Ayesha causes Mrs Tembe to pause for thought and a patient's problems put Al in an unusual situation.(n)

programme.title: Telly Bingo
programme.desc: Lottery game show, presented by Declan Buckley.(n)

programme.title: RTÉ News: One O'Clock and Weather
programme.desc: National and international news.(n)

programme.title: Home and Away
programme.desc: Sun-kissed Australian soap charting the latest comings and goings of the Summer Bay regulars.(n)

programme.title: Neighbours
programme.desc: Sparks fly between Piper and Tyler and she invites him to her place, while John discovers a clue to his past when he recognises a woman on the street.(n)

programme.title: Neven Maguire: Home Chef
programme.desc: Chef Pat Kiely from Cork's award-winning restaurant Les Gourmandises prepares top side of beef, and Neven cooks fragrant roast chicken with sausage stuffing, and ravioli of Swiss chard and ricotta with smoked garlic foam.(n)

programme.title: Fair City
programme.desc: Niamh plays nice with Oisin, under the impression that Nicola's imminent arrival will mean he will soon be returning to Cork. However, Nicola and her tearaway son have other plans. Robbie makes contact with a man who claims to have known his mother, and Debbie worries about Emmet after he makes a video in which he threatens pranksters who have been tormenting the family over Katy's disappearance.(n)

programme.title: Tracks and Trails
programme.desc: Meteorologist and TV weather presenter Gerry Murphy walks the 15km journey on Valentia Island in Kerry, ending at Bray Head. His second walk takes him to Derrynane, which is the ancestral home of Daniel O'Connell, one of Ireland's most historic figures.(n)

programme.title: What Are You Eating
programme.desc: Up until the 1950s, food was a relatively simple matter, with narrow choice and a constant battle to keep food fresh. Fast forward to the present day and mass production, intensive farming, refrigeration, freezing and food technology have provided more choice and lower prices. However, a sizeable proportion of food is now processed to maintain freshness, leading presenter Philip Boucher-Hayes to ask if people really know what they are eating. In the first edition, the presenter examines how the Irish consumer has changed over the years, and is joined by chef Hilary O'Hagan to look at processed meat products and the Paleo diet.(n)

programme.title: Today
programme.desc: Daily magazine show featuring entertainment and celebrity news, consumer advice, and Ireland's biggest giveaways. Presented by Daithi O Se and Maura Derrane.(n)

programme.title: Nuacht
programme.desc: The latest news headlines.(n)

programme.title: RTÉ News: Six One and Weather
programme.desc: The latest national and international headlines.(n)

programme.title: Getaways
programme.desc: Joe Lindsay and Angela Scanlon visit the Greek island of Zante, or Zakynthos, famed for its white beaches. Angela also sails across to Olympia, birthplace of the Olympic Games.(n)

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: As the day of Max's court hearing arrives, Lauren wants to be there for her dad - but when Abi says she cannot face him, the sisters write a letter in the hope of reaching out to him and becoming a family again. Kim tries to persuade Vincent not to have a baby with another woman, while Pam suggests Ben should stay for the night, unaware Christine is back in Les's life. Louise manipulates Bex in her attempt to win Shakil.(n)

programme.title: Fair City
programme.desc: Oisin tries to play Paul off against Niamh, who has made it very clear she wants him gone from the Brennan household. Robbie's meeting with Colin brings bad news, and Ray worries Hayley is taking advantage of Mondo's kindness.(n)

programme.title: The Shelbourne
programme.desc: The inner workings of the Dublin five-star hotel. Sommelier Nisea demonstrates the art of spitting out wine properly and Doiran prepares a room for a multimillionaire guest.(n)

programme.title: RTÉ News: Nine O'Clock and Weather
programme.desc: The latest national and international news.(n)

programme.title: Prime Time
programme.desc: Current affairs review, covering political and social topics at home and abroad, plus local and international headlines.(n)

programme.title: American Crime Story
programme.sub-title: The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story: From the Ashes of Tragedy
programme.desc: New series. Fact-based crime drama about the trial of former American football star and actor OJ Simpson for the murders of his wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman. In June 1994, LAPD detectives quickly link a double homicide to OJ Simpson, but his celebrity status makes them unsure how to handle matters. Marcia Clark in the district attorney's office advises a swift arrest, but flamboyant Hollywood lawyer Robert Shapiro gets involved and events start to spiral out of control. Starring Cuba Gooding Jr, John Travolta, Sarah Paulson and David Schwimmer.(n)

programme.title: The Good Wife
programme.desc: After seven series of legal wranglings, domestic drama and political intrigue, the US drama reaches its conclusion with Alicia (Julianna Margulies) looking to the future. Meanwhile, Peter has little time left to make a plea deal before the jury comes back with a verdict. Last in the series.(n)

programme.title: The Graham Norton Show
programme.desc: Comic actors Kelsey Grammer and Tamsin Greig, co-stars of Breaking the Bank join the host to discuss the new comedy release. Plus, Oscar-nominated star Salma Hayek promotes her new movie, Tale of Tales, and singer-songwriter Alicia Keys performs her new single In Common. The host also subjects more audience members to the dreaded red chair - so their stories had better be good.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Crimewatch Roadshow
programme.desc: Michelle Ackerley joins the Met's Marine Unit for a shift on the Thames, and Rav Wilding is joined in the studio by a choir whose members are all in search of missing loved ones.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Lucy Alexander, Martin Roberts and Dion Dublin explore properties about to be auctioned in Catford, London, in Liverpool, near the river Mersey, and in Alvaston, Derby.

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: Maureen Cooper takes her sons to meet their relatives for the first time, and Wendy Stringer searches for her half-brother, John, who was re-homed during the Second World War.

programme.title: Break-in Britain - The Crackdown
programme.desc: Dan Donnelly helps a mother in Leeds after a burglar steals her children's toys and he is determined to make a care worker's home more secure so that she can feel safe.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Two teams are given an hour to buy three items at the Lincolnshire Showground to take to auction. Tim Wonnacott observes proceedings, and Mark Stacey and Natasha Raskin assist the participants by offering their expert opinion.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.sub-title: In Every Home a Heartache - Part Two
programme.desc: Part two of two. Emma struggles to maintain her equilibrium as the police investigation into Nicholas's death gathers pace. Medical drama, starring Dido Miles.

programme.title: For What It's Worth
programme.desc: Fern Britton hosts the quiz in which three pairs of contestants try to amass antiques and collectibles by answering general knowledge questions. Anita Manning is today's expert.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: With a budget of £300k, Nicki Chapman is property shopping with a buyer looking to swap the hustle and busy of London for the tranquillity of the Shropshire countryside.

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Presenter Helen Skelton and expert garden designer Danny Clarke transform a tiny back yard into a beach garden inspired by the neighbouring Barry coastline.

programme.title: Flog It
programme.desc: Antiques experts Claire Rawle and Adam Partridge appraise collectables that reflect local Kent character at Chiddingstone Castle. Meanwhile, presenter Paul Martin visits Anne Boleyn's family home of Hever Castle to reveal what influenced her rise to power.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Another mix of nationwide reports and live studio-based chat, hosted by Matt Baker and Alex Jones.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: Paul encourages Les to take a stand, so he visits Babe and tells her he is prepared to go to the police - even if it means the truth about Christine coming out. Vincent is in two minds about fathering Donna's baby, but agrees to talk to Kim about it - although his attempts are thwarted when a furious Carmel turns up wanting to know why she was banned from the salsa show. Lauren grows frustrated when Ian locks himself away and ignores his grandson, so she confronts him about it, while Ronnie goes on a double date with an anxious Roxy.

programme.title: Holby City
programme.desc: Arthur and Morven make a decision about their future, Dom battles with his guilt over letting down a friend and Zosia questions where her loyalties lie. Medical drama, starring Rob Ostlere and Eleanor Fanyinka.

programme.title: In the Club
programme.desc: Jasmin and Dev are busy preparing for daughter Amber's Hindu naming ceremony, but when Vicky arrives, their plans are thrown into chaos as Jasmin is rushed into hospital. Meanwhile, a heartbroken Roanna has to face the consequences of her actions when she visits Jonathan in hospital. With Kim's maternity leave over she has to return to work, but struggles to leave baby Emily at nursery for the first time. Last in the series.

programme.title: Thierry Henry: My France, My Euros
programme.desc: The former France striker and Arsenal's all-time leading scorer looks at European Championship stories, assessing the social and cultural impact football has across the continent. As Henry's home country prepares to host Euro 2016 following last November's terror attacks in Paris, he explores how the beautiful game can unify a nation, from the success of the Netherlands in 1988 to Euro 96 in England, when `football came home'. Contributors include Cesc Fabregas, Peter Schmeichel, Ruud Gullit, Jurgen Klinsmann, Alan Shearer, David Baddiel and Ian Broudie.

programme.title: The Truth About
programme.desc: In the last of three documentaries focusing on medical matters, Fiona Phillips teams up with leading scientists to investigate how people can eat and drink their way to good health - and uncovers some surprising truths along the way. She reveals which everyday foods provide the benefits of so-called `superfoods' at a fraction of the price, tests some of the top-selling health drinks and supplements, and asks whether antioxidant smoothies really give the boost that people think. She also sets out to find the healthiest breakfast, discovering whether cereal and fruit really is better than bacon and eggs. Last in the series.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Crimewatch Roadshow
programme.desc: Roving reporter Michelle Ackerley learns to deal with rioters at the Met's public order training centre in Gravesend, while Rav Wilding looks at the unsolved murder of Melanie Hall.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Lucy Alexander, Martin Roberts and Dion Dublin explore properties about to be auctioned in Buckinghamshire, Surrey and Lancashire, then talk to the buyers about their plans.

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: A family tracing agency steps in to help reunite two brothers, Fred and Jimmy O'Donnell, who spent 80 years apart after their Irish mother gave birth to them out of wedlock.

programme.title: Break-in Britain - The Crackdown
programme.desc: Beer-guzzling burglars in Leeds is caught on camera making their escape, while stolen items are found dumped by the side of the road in Swansea.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: A pair of paramedics and two animal enthusiasts select antiques for auction in Newark, with the help of experts Richard Madley and Catherine Southon. Tim Wonnacott presents.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Emma feels helpless as the police investigation ramps up, and Rhiannon comes under the spotlight. Medical drama, starring Owen Brenman and Adrian Lewis Morgan.

programme.title: For What It's Worth
programme.desc: Fern Britton hosts the game show in which three pairs of contestants try to amass a valuable collection of antiques and collectibles by answering general knowledge questions, with the value of the items they win being converted to a cash prize. This time, she is joined by antiques expert Charles Hanson.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Jonnie Irwin helps a Reiki therapist and a carpenter search for a peaceful country home in south Lincolnshire with a budget of £270,000. He also meets the owner of Doddington Hall, an Elizabethan stately home, where a number of rare tapestries are being restored.

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Helen Skelton and garden designer Danny Clarke help an urban community farm in Southampton create a sheltered seating area, with a fire-pit for marshmallow toasting.

programme.title: Flog It
programme.desc: People are invited to try to make money out of their antiques by taking a risk at auction.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: Referendum Campaign Broadcast
programme.desc: A referendum broadcast by the Britain Stronger in Europe campaign, ahead of the referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union on June 23, 2016.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Alex Jones host the live magazine show, with a team of roving reporters presenting stories of interest from around the UK, plus big-name studio guests.

programme.title: The Andrew Neil Interviews: Leave or Remain
programme.desc: The broadcaster and political journalist talks to leading figures from the Britain Stronger in Europe and Vote Leave campaigns ahead of the referendum on the European Union on June 23.

programme.title: Lose Weight for Love
programme.desc: Psychologist Tanya Byron and her team separate a couple for ten weeks in a bid to end their self-destructive behaviour. Lisa, who is clinically obese at over 22 stones, is unable to get pregnant due to her weight, and Steve, who is suffering from type two diabetes, fears he and his partner will not grow old together. Last in the series.

programme.title: The Big C & Me
programme.desc: Cameras follow three more families whose lives have been reshaped by a cancer diagnosis, including 83-year-old June, whose family must face up to her imminent death when she learns she has pancreatic cancer. Nine-year-old Mikey has been diagnosed with a brain tumour and begins chemotherapy, but as his treatment progresses, his cancer brings together both his family and the local community. Meanwhile, 17-year-old Phoebe is receiving treatment for a tumour on her kidney and uses a blog to vent her changing emotions.

programme.title: Football Focus
programme.desc: Gary Lineker looks ahead to the tournament, which starts at the Stade de France in Paris on Friday when the hosts take on Romania. The month-long showcase has been expanded to 24 teams for the first time, and British interest will focus on England, Northern Ireland and Wales, along with the Republic of Ireland, who all qualified for the finals, with arguably the standout tie of the group stage being England v Wales on 16 June in Lens.

programme.title: A Question of Sport
programme.desc: Stoke City and England goalkeeper Jack Butland, England rugby union international Maggie Alphonsi, former swimmer Steve Parry and Commonwealth silver medal-winning sprinter Christian Malcolm join team captains Matt Dawson and Phil Tufnell for the light-hearted quiz. Sue Barker asks the questions.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.(n)

programme.title: Crimewatch Roadshow
programme.desc: Michelle Ackerley is in Hertfordshire finding out how the nation's historic treasures are being plundered illegally, and Rav Wilding handles some police dogs in the studio.(n)

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: The team follow more properties from auction room to renovation, visiting an end terrace in Derby, a mid-terrace in Co Durham and a three-storey property in the Rhondda Valley.(n)

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: Twins look for their half-sister who was born while their father was away in the Second World War. Plus, a Pakistani woman who has been trying to trace her grandmother for 10 years.(n)

programme.title: Break-in Britain - The Crackdown
programme.desc: In West Yorkshire, Dan Donnelly meets former university lecturer Ken, whose home was broken into as he slept. Various items, including his laptop which contained photographs of his late wife, were stolen, so Dan boosts his security with a large back gate. Meanwhile, Keeley Donovan visits retired missionary Jean in South Wales, who was burgled for the second time while she was out.(n)

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Natasha Raskin presents from Leominster, Herefordshire, as Paul Laidlaw and Mark Ashley help the teams raise the most money. Natasha also shows off her favourite ceramic frog.(n)

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Valerie enlists the help of Al to find a special person she needs to thank. The police investigation takes an unexpected turn, while Emma does some serious soul-searching.(n)

programme.title: For What It's Worth
programme.desc: Fern Britton hosts the game show in which three pairs of contestants try to win antiques and collectibles to be converted into cash. With the help of antiques expert Charlie Ross.(n)

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Alistair Appleton travels to the Peak District to help a couple who have £500,000 to buy their first property together. He also meets a farmer who is growing a field of furniture.(n)

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Helen Skelton and Danny Clarke help a 200m para-athlete transform his boring but private Fareham back garden into a beautiful sanctuary.(n)

programme.title: Flog It
programme.desc: Antiques experts Mark Stacey and Michael Baggott appraise an array of collectibles and antiques at Southwell Minster, Nottinghamshire, including a classic Rolling Stones LP and a haul of Russian silver. Presenter Paul Martin also finds time to explore the county's Newstead Abbey, once home to 19th-century poet Lord Byron.(n)

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.(n)

programme.title: Referendum Campaign Broadcast
programme.desc: By the Vote Leave campaign.(n)

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Alex Jones present the live magazine show featuring a mixture of celebrity chat and stories of interest.(n)

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: As the day of Max's court hearing arrives, Lauren wants to be there for her dad - but when Abi says she cannot face him, the sisters write a letter in the hope of reaching out to him and becoming a family again. Kim tries to persuade Vincent not to have a baby with another woman, while Pam suggests Ben should stay for the night, unaware Christine is back in Les's life. Louise manipulates Bex in her attempt to win Shakil.(n)

programme.title: DIY SOS
programme.sub-title: DIY SOS: The Big Build: Shropshire
programme.desc: Nick Knowles travels to Hopesay, Shropshire to meet ex-fireman Joe and his seven-year-old daughter Lucy. Joe lost his wife Jess suddenly in 2014, partway through renovating an old cottage into what they had hoped would be a dream family home. Now work has ground to a halt and Joe and his daughter are living in a tiny caravan in the garden. Having heard of their plight, the DIY SOS team arrives to give them the home Jess had wanted for them, backed up by an army of local tradespeople.(n)

programme.title: New Blood
programme.desc: New series. Six years after a sinister drugs trial in India, one of the participants is found dead - and although it is ruled as suicide, eager young PC Rash Sayyad is sure it's murder, impressing DS Sands so much that he offers him a trainee detective position. But as they begin to follow up on the junior cop's suspicions, Serious Fraud Office investigator Stefan Kowolski is gathering intelligence on a hospital pharmacist - eventually drawing him into the same case. Crime drama written by Anthony Horowitz, starring Mark Addy, Ben Tavassoli, Mark Strepan and Anna Chancellor.(n)

programme.title: Question Time
programme.desc: David Dimbleby chairs the debate from Folkestone, with a panel of politicians and other guests facing topical questions from the audience.(n)

programme.title: This Week
programme.desc: Andrew Neil presents round-table chat, in which he and his guests take a light-hearted romp through the political and parliamentary developments of the past seven days. They'll be discussing who is making the headlines and the issues that matter to both MPs and the public.(n)

programme.title: City in the Sky
programme.desc: New series. Dallas Campbell and Dr Hannah Fry present a documentary exploring aviation, beginning with a look at the challenges of getting aircraft into the air. The programme features a visit to the world's busiest airport to discover the work that goes into getting its millions of visitors off the ground. Plus, the construction of the world's largest passenger plane and the dangers of taking off from the coldest city on Earth.

programme.title: Living with Dementia: Chris's Story
programme.desc: Documentary filmed over almost two years, following 55-year-old Chris Roberts from North Wales as he, his wife Jayne and his youngest daughter Kate come to terms with his Alzheimer's diagnosis. The programme reveals what life is really like for a family living with dementia using CCTV cameras, video diaries and a small film crew. Once a businessman and a keen biker, Chris chronicles his changing life as his independence slips away, from choosing a care home and writing a will, to getting lost in his own house and not recognising his family.

programme.title: Lose Weight for Love
programme.desc: Clinical psychologist Tanya Byron comes to the aid of another couple whose diet is causing problems in their relationship. Celena has gained five stone since getting together with Peter, who does all the cooking at home, producing high-fat, high-sugar dishes for the pair of them to eat. Celena's weight issues are stopping her from enjoying life - she won't go on holiday, have her son christened, or even marry Peter. Tanya steps in to resolve the pair's dilemma, sending them off on separate, 10-week courses that incorporate new diets and fitness plans. Plus, behavioural scientist Professor Paul Dolan seeks to retrain Peter's taste-buds after Tanya gets to the bottom of his hatred of vegetables.

programme.title: The Truth About
programme.desc: Doctor Javid Abdelmoneim explores the science behind drinking alcohol, including why the weekly recommended intake was lowered in January, with the men's limit cut by a third to 14 units per week. He also asks whether a nightcap can aid sleep, why some people get drunk quicker than others, what is behind the relatively healthy reputation of red wine and whether lining your stomach before drinking really lessens the effects of a night out. Plus, he assesses new evidence for the health risks posed by alcohol.

programme.title: This Is BBC Two
programme.desc: Preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.

programme.title: Flog It! Trade Secrets
programme.desc: The team offers advice on what to look out for in the world of Victoriana. Paul Martin visits Wellington College, Caroline Hawley explains her passion for vesta cases and there is a look at what made the Victorians such masters of invention.

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: A genealogist helps a man make contact with his birth mother, while a businessman from Syria is reunited with his family in the UK after seven months apart.

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Helen Skelton and designer Danny Clarke attempt to transform a stagnant, weed-choked pond into a haven both for its owners and the local wildlife.

programme.title: The Hairy Bikers' Pubs That Built Britain
programme.desc: Si and Dave are in Glasgow, discovering pubs with a link to the city's shipbuilding industry. They meet former shipyard workers to hear what pub life was like when the whistles blew, Si tries his hand at welding, and the duo celebrate the city's illustrious past with some cocktail-making in a bar said to be styled on the Clyde-built ship, The Queen Mary.

programme.title: The Extraordinary Collector
programme.desc: Following art dealer Gordon Watson, as he stakes his money and reputation on buying, selling and getting the best deals for his wealthy clients. In the first programme, he views the latest additions to Lord Rothschild's collection of traditional and contemporary art, furniture and design, to see whether there is anything he can add. Gordon also receives a tour of Flint House, a new-build on Rothschild's Buckinghamshire estate. Inspired by ideas of what he might sell to the peer, Gordon heads to Amsterdam to see an unique piece of contemporary lighting he has been advised about.

programme.title: Victoria Derbyshire
programme.desc: Daily news and current-affairs programme offering discussion of breaking stories, exclusive interviews and audience interaction via social media.

programme.title: BBC Newsroom Live
programme.desc: A chance to stay up to date on the day's leading stories, with the latest breaking news as it happens.

programme.title: Daily Politics
programme.desc: Parliamentary proceedings interspersed with discussions, interviews and filmed reports from around the country. Presented by Jo Coburn.

programme.title: The Super League Show
programme.desc: Tanya Arnold introduces action from the latest Super League matches, which included Hull FC v Widnes Vikings, St Helens v Warrington Wolves, and Leeds Rhinos v Catalan Dragons.

programme.title: The TV That Made Me
programme.desc: Entrepreneur Duncan Bannatyne joins host Brian Conley for a nostalgic look at the archive television shows that helped set him on the path to business success, with selections including Take Your Pick and Coronation Street.

programme.title: Sacred Rivers with Simon Reeve
programme.desc: The adventurer travels to China for a trip along the Yangtze, Asia's longest river and the third longest in the world. He follows the route to Dazu, where he sees 50,000 ancient rock carvings, some of the only religious artefacts not to have been destroyed under communist rule. He then takes a river cruise to the Three Gorges Dam - the biggest power station on the planet - before ending his journey in Shanghai, a shining symbol of China's new economic might and a city where many are rediscovering religious faith. Last in the series.

programme.title: The Big Allotment Challenge
programme.desc: Fern Britton presents as the five remaining pairs of gardeners battle it out for a place in the final, beginning by presenting onions and chrysanthemums for the scrutiny of Jim Buttress. Jonathan Moseley asks them to create a pedestal of flowers and Thane Prince sets them the challenge of making well-set jellies and fruit butters, before the judges decide which two of the teams will be leaving the competition.

programme.title: Great Continental Railway Journeys
programme.desc: Michael Portillo follows in the footsteps of Edwardian travellers to trace a route recommended in his Bradshaw's guide from the heart of France to the Mediterranean coast. His journey begins in Lyon, where he learns how the city got its gastronomic reputation, and takes instruction from a leading chef on making an omelette. In Avignon, he samples a glass of the region's famous wine Chateauneuf-du-Pape, before his journey ends at the Mediterranean port of Marseille, where he joins a pilot boat as it leads a supertanker to its berth.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Two married couples take up the challenge in Brampton, Cumbria, as they battle to find three items to make a profit at auction, with help from experts Anita Manning and David Harper. Tim Wonnacott hosts.

programme.title: Eggheads
programme.desc: Quiz in which the winners of famous game shows work as a team to tackle a new set of challengers hoping to win a cash prize. Jeremy Vine presents.

programme.title: Springwatch Unsprung
programme.desc: Chris Packham is joined by singer Will Young and broadcaster Clive Anderson at RSPB Minsmere in Suffolk, while Lindsey Chapman discusses viewers' questions with the panel.

programme.title: Antiques Road Trip
programme.desc: Auctioneers Catherine Southon and Paul Laidlaw continue the Northern Ireland leg of their journey, starting from Aghadowey, County Londonderry. They uncover some hidden gems to take to auction in Edinburgh, Scotland. Catherine uncovers a pair of vintage glove puppets, but will they give her a helping hand to defeat Paul in the saleroom?.

programme.title: Springwatch
programme.desc: Chris Packham, Martin Hughes-Games and Michaela Strachan continue their wildlife watch live from the RSPB's Minsmere reserve in Suffolk. Iolo Williams is in the British version of the Galapagos - the Farne Islands in Northumberland, and there are also reports on the Wild Boar in the Forest of Dean.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.sub-title: Horizon: Why Are We Getting So Fat?
programme.desc: With more than half of the UK's adults are currently overweight, Cambridge geneticist Dr Giles Yeo believes that for many obese people, simply eating less is a harder than some might think. He takes a road trip around the UK and America to uncover why, meets people behind some of the shocking newspaper headlines, and through their stories, reveals truths which dispel commonly held myths about obesity.

programme.title: Jack Dee's Referendum Help Desk
programme.desc: New series. The comedian turned agony uncle helps a studio audience dispel their problems, and sheds light on dilemmas and issues relating to the EU Referendum. He's assisted by a panel of four comedic guests, with Romesh Ranganathan and Katherine Ryan among those featured in the first episode.

programme.title: Newsnight
programme.desc: Analysis of the day's events, presented by Evan Davis.

programme.title: American Crime Story
programme.sub-title: The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story: The Run of His Life
programme.desc: Having fled with Al Cowlings in the white Ford Bronco before the police arrived to arrest him for the murders of his wife Nicole and her friend Ronald Goldman, OJ Simpson becomes a hunted man as the district attorney's office and the LAPD scramble to save face and find him. Meanwhile, the former American football star's lawyers Robert Shapiro and Robert Kardashian have to deal with the fallout, and call a press conference. Fact-based drama, starring Cuba Gooding Jr, John Travolta and David Schwimmer. Continues tomorrow.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.sub-title: Horizon: How to Find Love Online
programme.desc: Mathematician Hannah Fry uses doctor and broadcaster Xand van Tulleken as a guinea pig to test whether the algorithms that dating sites use to match people actually work. Xand gets advice from scientists on what to write in his profile, has an MRI scan to find out whether his brain is equipped for love and goes on various dates to test whether the algorithm makes better matches than him choosing randomly.

programme.title: Nature's Epic Journeys
programme.desc: Documentary following thousands of zebra as they face lions, hunting dogs, drought and starvation to undertake the world's most newly discovered migration. Braving one of Botswana's most brutal wildernesses along the way, the animals make Africa's longest land migration to reach the grasslands of Nxai Pan National Park. Liz Bonnin and a team of scientists and filmmakers use cutting-edge technology to capture the zebra every step of the way, and reveal the secrets behind the brand new finding. Last in the series.

programme.title: This Farming Life
programme.desc: Summer arrives, and in the east of Scotland, Martin prepares two young bulls for the biggest event of the farming calendar - the Royal Highland Show in Edinburgh. First they need their nose rings, an accessory no bull can do without. Martin and Mel's wedding is also looming, and while he goes for his final kilt fitting, Mel meets her Dad to discuss their plans.

programme.title: This Is BBC Two
programme.desc: Preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.

programme.title: Flog It! Trade Secrets
programme.desc: Paul Martin and the show's experts examine all manner of antiques and collectibles that have been inspired by the natural world, from a valuable old papier mache cow to the charms of Steiff teddy bears.

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: Maureen Cooper takes her sons to meet their relatives for the first time, and Wendy Stringer searches for her half-brother, John, who was re-homed during the Second World War.

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Presenter Helen Skelton and expert garden designer Danny Clarke transform a tiny back yard into a beach garden inspired by the neighbouring Barry coastline.

programme.title: Great British Menu
programme.desc: The finalists cook their main courses as they battle it out under the watchful eye of a panel of judges, with the aim of getting a dish shortlisted and proving themselves worthy of the chance to reach the WI banquet. However, the standards are higher than ever before and the chefs are feeling the pressure.

programme.title: Victoria Derbyshire
programme.desc: Daily news and current-affairs programme offering discussion of breaking stories, exclusive interviews and audience interaction via social media.

programme.title: BBC Newsroom Live
programme.desc: A chance to stay up to date on the day's leading stories, with the latest breaking news as it happens.

programme.title: Daily Politics
programme.desc: Coverage of Prime Minister's Questions from the House of Commons at 12.00, interspersed with discussions, interviews and reports from around the country. Presented by Andrew Neil and Jo Coburn.

programme.title: Pressure Pad
programme.desc: General knowledge quiz, hosted by John Barrowman, in which two teams of five players are pitted against each other inside an illuminated arena, known as the Pressure Pad. The team with the most players remaining for the final round will put itself in the strongest position to win the rolling jackpot on offer.

programme.title: The TV That Made Me
programme.desc: Swimmer Rebecca Adlington joins comedy entertainer Brian Conley for a nostalgic look at the archive television programmes that helped set her on the path to Olympic success. Her selections include Fawlty Towers, Blind Date and Art Attack.

programme.title: Monkey Planet
programme.desc: Zoologist George McGavin explores the world of primates, from strange lemurs and acrobatic monkeys to enigmatic apes. He uncovers the secrets of the primates' success - their survival tactics and physical adaptations - and how their lives mirror those of their human cousins. He begins by meeting an orang-utan that uses soap to improve its personal hygiene, baboons with a taste for flamingos, criminal-minded macaques and fluorescent mandrills that don warpaint before going into battle.

programme.title: The Big Allotment Challenge
programme.desc: Fern Britton presents as the three remaining pairs of gardeners battle it out to be crowned the winners of the competition. Jim Buttress asks them to present melon and sweetcorn to the show bench, Jonathan Moseley challenges them to create a suspended floral design including dahlias and Thane Prince gives them the task of making a gift basket full of produce from their allotments. Who will succeed and be crowned the first winners of the contest? Last in the series.

programme.title: Great Continental Railway Journeys
programme.desc: Michael Portillo ventures onto the European rail network to retrace journeys featured in Bradshaw's Continental Railway Guide of 1913, beginning with London to Monte Carlo. His first stop is Paris, where he absorbs the atmosphere, before heading south to the Cote d'Azur and ending his journey at Monaco's gaming tables.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Kate Bliss and Jeremy Lamond assist two teams who are challenged to pick up bargains at a maze-like antiques centre in Farnham, Surrey, before taking the items to auction. Presenter Tim Wonnacott also visits Clandon Park, a National Trust property dating back to the 18th century.

programme.title: Referendum Campaign Broadcast
programme.desc: A referendum broadcast by the Britain Stronger in Europe campaign, ahead of the referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union on June 23, 2016.

programme.title: Eggheads
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Jeremy Vine, in which the winners of famous game shows work as a team to tackle a new set of challengers hoping to win a cash prize.

programme.title: Springwatch Unsprung
programme.desc: Chris Packham is joined on the sofa by poet and playwright Benjamin Zephaniah. He also meets young people with a passion for wildlife, and presents some `Unsprung Hero' awards.

programme.title: Antiques Road Trip
programme.desc: Antiques experts Paul Laidlaw and Catherine Southon search for bargains in Scotland, beginning in Callander and shopping in Perthshire and Angus, before heading to the final battle at auction in Stirlingshire. Along the way, Paul finds out about Andrew Carnegie, who was once the world's richest man, and Catherine tries to haggle dealers for the best price.

programme.title: Springwatch
programme.desc: Chris Packham and Michaela Strachan share overnight breaking news from the wildlife cameras, while Martin Hughes-Games joins in with the vital monitoring of animals on the reserve. Iolo Williams introduces the latest from the seabird colony on the Farne Islands, plus there is a report from the Golden Eagles in Scotland.

programme.title: Versailles
programme.desc: As the series continues, harsh steps must be taken to ensure that the royal reputation is preserved. Meanwhile, flamboyant Philippe causes a stir of his own, and elsewhere, the King hopes that humiliating a suspect noble will in turn bring others to heel. Period drama depicting the infidelities and intrigues at the court of Louis XIV, during the monarch's early reign. Supported by Inside Versailles documentary shorts. Starring George Blagden, Evan Williams, Alexander Vlahos and Stuart Bowman.

programme.title: QI
programme.desc: Correctness and even intelligence go out of the window in this quiz, as host Stephen Fry awards points for answers he finds most interesting. This edition sees Noel Fielding, Rhod Gilbert and Cariad Lloyd join regular panellist Alan Davies to tackle miscellaneous M-themed matters.

programme.title: Newsnight
programme.desc: Analysis of the day's events, presented by Emily Maitlis.

programme.title: American Crime Story
programme.sub-title: The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story: The Dream Team
programme.desc: Ridiculed defence lawyer Robert Shapiro shops around for support as he attempts to form a formidable legal team to cope with the weight of evidence stacked against his client, while practicality and politics dictate the prosecution's approach. However, neither side is prepared for the revelation of evidence that further inflames public opinion, and the effect of tabloid `cash for trash' stories takes its toll. Fact-based drama, starring Cuba Gooding Jr, John Travolta, David Schwimmer and Courtney B Vance.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.sub-title: Horizon: Why Are We Getting So Fat?
programme.desc: With more than half of the UK's adults are currently overweight, Cambridge geneticist Dr Giles Yeo believes that for many obese people, simply eating less is a harder than some might think. He takes a road trip around the UK and America to uncover why, meets people behind some of the shocking newspaper headlines, and through their stories, reveals truths which dispel commonly held myths about obesity.

programme.title: World Cup 1966: Alfie's Boys
programme.desc: David Jason presents a documentary about how Alf Ramsey recruited the England football team that won the world cup in 1966, and was able to unite the members into a world class side. Featuring archive footage of the team in action and contributions from Bobby Charlton, Jack Charlton, Jimmy Greaves, George Cohen, Tina Moore, Harry Redknapp, Terry Venables, Geoff Hurst and Gordon Banks.(n)

programme.title: Jimmy Hill - A Man for All Seasons
programme.desc: A profile of the former footballer and pundit, who died in December 2015, and will be best remembered for campaigning to abolish the maximum wage for footballers in the 1960s. Featuring contributions from Gary Lineker, Mark Lawrenson, Alan Hansen, Gabby Logan, Greg Dyke, Sir Alex Ferguson, Peter Alliss and Terry Venables, plus his widow Bryony and son Jamie.(n)

programme.title: This Is BBC Two
programme.desc: Preview of upcoming programmes from BBC Two.(n)

programme.title: Flog It! Trade Secrets
programme.desc: Paul Martin and the team explore weird and wonderful items, and expert Philip Serrell reveals some of the oddities in his own collection, including an unusual desk top object.(n)

programme.title: Family Finders
programme.desc: A family tracing agency steps in to help reunite two brothers, Fred and Jimmy O'Donnell, who spent 80 years apart after their Irish mother gave birth to them out of wedlock.(n)

programme.title: The Instant Gardener
programme.desc: Helen Skelton and garden designer Danny Clarke help an urban community farm in Southampton create a sheltered seating area, with a fire-pit for marshmallow toasting.(n)

programme.title: The Great British Sewing Bee
programme.desc: Claudia Winkleman welcomes 10 more hopefuls as the amateur sewing competition returns, with Patrick Grant being joined on the judging team by Esme Young, co-founder of fashion label Swanky Modes and tutor in pattern-cutting at Central Saint Martins art school in London. The first challenge sees the contestants follow a deceptively difficult pattern for a woman's top made up of four pieces, before they have to transform a maternity dress in just 90 mins and fit a skirt to a real model in the final task.(n)

programme.title: Victoria Derbyshire
programme.desc: Daily news and current-affairs programme offering discussion of breaking stories, exclusive interviews and audience interaction via social media.(n)

programme.title: BBC Newsroom Live
programme.desc: A chance to stay up to date on the day's leading stories, with the latest breaking news as it happens.(n)

programme.title: Daily Politics
programme.desc: Parliamentary proceedings interspersed with discussions, interviews and filmed reports from around the country. Presented by Andrew Neil and Jo Coburn.(n)

programme.title: Pressure Pad
programme.desc: General knowledge quiz, hosted by John Barrowman, in which two teams of five players are pitted against each other inside an illuminated arena, known as the Pressure Pad. The team with the most players remaining for the final round will put itself in the strongest position to win the jackpot, which starts at £3,000. The prize money rolls over to the next week's competition if neither team is victorious.(n)

programme.title: The TV That Made Me
programme.desc: Comedian, actor and Cold Feet star John Thomson tells Brian Conley about the early TV programmes and adverts that shaped his life, from his love of Batman to his hatred of Bungle.(n)

programme.title: Monkey Planet
programme.desc: Zoologist George McGavin continues his exploration of the primate world, considering how the secret to their success is the ability to live in close-knit family and social groups. This is demonstrated by the emperor tamarin males conned into childcare in Peru and the South African vervet monkeys that have a sophisticated alarm system to protect them from predators. But living together often has its problems, like the Barbary macaques in Gibraltar who have their babies stolen by others out to impress their boss, the matriarchal ring-tailed lemur societies where females battle one another with their children in tow, and the hamadryas baboons of Ethiopia where the males rule with an iron fist.(n)

programme.title: The Big Allotment Challenge
programme.desc: Fern Britton presents the return of the contest, which this time pits nine gardeners against one another as they attempt to impress Royal Horticultural Society judge Jim Buttress, floral designer Jonathan Moseley and food writer Thane Prince. In the first episode, the contenders must grow and present five matching new potatoes and three perfect stems of zinnia, create floral baskets and finally make two sauces for a Sunday roast, before the three experts decide who will be first to leave the allotment.(n)

programme.title: Great Continental Railway Journeys
programme.desc: Armed with his trusty copy of Bradshaw's Continental Railway Guide of 1913, Michael Portillo explores the former domain of the Habsburg monarchs, beginning in the Hungarian capital Budapest. He then travels to Austria via Bratislava in Slovakia, and in Vienna he immerses himself in pre-First World War decadence. From there he heads to Salzburg, before going on to the Salzkammergut region to visit the emperor's Austrian summer residence at Bad Ischl, where in 1914 Franz Joseph I signed a declaration that changed the course of European history.(n)

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Presenter Tim Wonnacott invites two teams to scour Westpoint Antiques Fair outside Exeter, Devon for bargains to sell for profit at auction. Advice is provided by Philip Serrell and Caroline Hawley.(n)

programme.title: Referendum Campaign Broadcast
programme.desc: By the Vote Leave campaign.(n)

programme.title: Eggheads
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Jeremy Vine, in which the winners of famous game shows work as a team to tackle a new set of challengers hoping to win a cash prize.(n)

programme.title: Springwatch Unsprung
programme.desc: Chris Packham presents another show live from Suffolk, where writer and broadcaster Germaine Greer joins him to talk bugs, and Lindsey Chapman takes audience questions.(n)

programme.title: Antiques Road Trip
programme.desc: Anita Manning and Philip Serrell kick off in the Lake District, before ending at their first auction in Lancashire. They then visit Co Durham and Driffield, East Yorkshire.(n)

programme.title: Springwatch
programme.desc: As another week for wildlife draws to a close on the Suffolk coast, Chris Packham and Michaela Strachan report live on all the latest action from RSPB Minsmere. Martin Hughes-Games is out on the reserve helping the local wildlife, and Iolo Williams has the latest on the shag and puffin dramas taking place on the Farne Islands. Plus, more ideas for viewers to get out this weekend and help wildlife as part of the Do Something Great campaign.(n)

programme.title: Peaky Blinders
programme.desc: The third run of Steven Knight's period drama reaches its final episode, and yet again Cillian Murphy as Thomas Shelby finds himself in a seemingly impossible situation. Has his criminal life finally caught up with the Birmingham-based mobster? Tommy prepares to commit the most audacious crime of his career, only to receive an unexpected blow that puts him under unbearable pressure. In a nerve-shredding race against time, Tommy is forced to confront hard truths about himself and his family that could change the Peaky Blinders for ever. As he faces his worst fears he needs help more than ever - but is increasingly uncertain about who he can trust. Last in the series.(n)

programme.title: Mock the Week
programme.desc: New series. In June 2005, Dara O Briain hit the screens with a new comedy panel show in which comedians were invited to comment on the week's events. It may not have been the first show to have done this, but its method of doing so - playing to the comics' strengths through stand-up spots and improvised games - quickly assured its success. It's still going strong 11 years later, and tonight it returns for a new run, with regular panellist Hugh Dennis joined by Gary Delaney, Ed Gamble, Nish Kumar, Tiff Stevenson and Josh.(n)

programme.title: Newsnight
programme.desc: Analysis of the day's events, presented by Kirsty Wark.(n)

programme.title: Top Gear
programme.desc: Chris Evans, Matt LeBlanc and Eddie Jordan head for South Africa, where Sharleen Spiteri, Seasick Steve and Tinie Tempah take part in an SUV test. Back at the track, Chris joins Jenson Button for a ride in the McLaren 675LT, while Damian Lewis is this week's Star in a Rallycross Car.(n)

programme.title: D-Day: The Last Heroes
programme.desc: Historian Dan Snow presents the first of a two-part documentary examining how two years of meticulous planning, espionage and the analysis of millions of 3D aerial photographs helped the Allied forces gain a foothold in northern France during the Second World War. He reveals how the June 1944 landings were conducted in two phases, an airborne assault and an amphibious landing. The essential element of surprise was upheld with some help from inclement weather and a comprehensive deception plan.

programme.title: Revolution and Romance: Musical Masters of the 19th Century
programme.desc: Suzy Klein explores the transformation of music in the era of Beethoven and Wagner, and in the first episode tells the story of an unrivalled creative outpouring. The presenter reveals how it was possible for composers and performers to become the superstars of their age, no longer the servants of kings and princes.

programme.title: Perfect Pianists at the BBC
programme.desc: David Owen Norris trawls through 60 years of BBC archive material to showcase some of the greatest names in the history of the piano. From the groundbreaking studio recitals of Benno Moiseiwitsch, Solomon and Myra Hess in the 1950s, through the legendary concerts of Vladimir Horowitz and Arthur Rubinstein to more recent performances including Alfred Brendel, Mitsuko Uchida and Stephen Hough, David celebrates some of the greatest players in a pianistic tradition that goes back to Franz Liszt in the 19th century.

programme.title: Storm Troupers: The Fight to Forecast the Weather
programme.desc: Alok Jha investigates how meteorology became one the most important scientific endeavours of the modern age by charting the progress of computer-based forecasting through the characters who pioneered it. He reveals how American mathematician Jule Charney found a way to simplify weather for the early computers of the 1940s, and looks at how John Mason gambled the future of the Met Office on unproven technology in the early 1960s. Last in the series.

programme.title: World News Today
programme.desc: The day's leading stories.

programme.title: Railway Walks
programme.sub-title: Railway Walks with Julia Bradbury: The Whisky Train
programme.desc: Julia visits north-east Scotland to walk along the Speyside Way. The route, which runs between the villages of Craigellachie and Ballindalloch, was the path of a railway that served a remote area and a world-famous drinks industry.

programme.title: Storm Troupers: The Fight to Forecast the Weather
programme.desc: Alok Jha investigates how meteorology became one the most important scientific endeavours of the modern age by charting the progress of computer-based forecasting through the characters who pioneered it. He reveals how American mathematician Jule Charney found a way to simplify weather for the early computers of the 1940s, and looks at how John Mason gambled the future of the Met Office on unproven technology in the early 1960s. Last in the series.

programme.title: Revolution and Romance: Musical Masters of the 19th Century
programme.desc: Suzy Klein investigates how music became a powerful force for Europe's citizens during the French Revolution. She reveals how music came to express not only revolutionary fervour, but also inspired a growing sense of nationalism that was sweeping the continent. Chopin's music, for example, expressed the defiant spirit of the Polish population suffering oppression under a foreign power.

programme.title: Seven Ages of Britain
programme.desc: David Dimbleby tells the story of the power struggle between the monarchy and the Church during the Middle Ages through treasures of the period, and reveals how the code of chivalry brought the two sides together. He also reassesses the cultural impact of Richard II's reign, and examines artefacts including the Mappa Mundi, Chaucer's Canterbury Tales and Britain's only preserved medieval crown.

programme.title: Hidden Killers
programme.sub-title: Hidden Killers of the Victorian Home
programme.desc: The first of two programmes in which historian Suzannah Lipscomb lays bare the dangers of domestic life in the 19th century, and reveals some of the harrowing consequences that resulted from urban growth, fashionable items and mass consumerism. She begins by examining how Victorian ladies surrounded themselves with highly dangerous new products, from the food they ate to the clothes they wore.

programme.title: Ben Building: Mussolini, Monuments and Modernism
programme.desc: Jonathan Meades travels to Rome, Milan, Genoa and the new town of Sabaudia as he turns his attention to the notorious 20th century European dictator, Mussolini. He examines the variety of styles of buildings of the fascist era that still shape architecture today, and considers the nature of fascism, the influence of The Futurists and Mussolini's love of a uniform.

programme.title: The Art of Gothic: Britain's Midnight Hour
programme.desc: Andrew Graham-Dixon examines England's Gothic Revival - an architectural movement that began in the mid-1700s. He starts by exploring its restrained aristocratic beginnings, then reveals how it went on to influence some of Britain's most famous artwork and buildings.

programme.title: Revolution and Romance: Musical Masters of the 19th Century
programme.desc: Suzy Klein investigates how music became a powerful force for Europe's citizens during the French Revolution. She reveals how music came to express not only revolutionary fervour, but also inspired a growing sense of nationalism that was sweeping the continent. Chopin's music, for example, expressed the defiant spirit of the Polish population suffering oppression under a foreign power.

programme.title: World News Today
programme.desc: The day's leading stories.

programme.title: Railway Walks
programme.sub-title: Railway Walks with Julia Bradbury: Harbouring History
programme.desc: Julia explores railway history in the streets of Weymouth. Tracing the route of a short Dorset line that once ran south from the town and across Chesil Beach and Portland, she learns about the history of Portland Harbour, and the stone that is the isle's most famous export.

programme.title: Dan Cruickshank: At Home with the British
programme.desc: Dan Cruickshank charts the rise and fall of high-rise flats by following the history of one estate - the 19-storey Lincoln in Bow, east London, designed in 1960. Last in the series.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.sub-title: Horizon: Man on Mars - Mission to the Red Planet
programme.desc: The programme goes behind the scenes at Nasa to discover how the space agency is preparing for its most ambitious and daring mission yet - to land a manned craft on the surface of Mars. Reaching the planet would involve a journey of at least three years, and the film meets the scientists and engineers who are designing new rockets and spacesuits, as well as finding ways to help astronauts survive the perils of such a long voyage.

programme.title: UK's Best Part-Time Band
programme.desc: Comedian Rhod Gilbert and Ultravox frontman Midge Ure set off on an epic road trip across Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales to discover Britain's finest music groups, witnessing musicians playing in rehearsal spaces, pubs, barns and bedrooms. From across the UK, more than 1,200 bands have entered the competition, playing rock to reggae, ska to skiffle, bhangra to blues and everything in between. Eventually five acts are selected for a regional heat in Belfast, where they compete for a place in the grand final.

programme.title: Ultimate Covers at the BBC
programme.desc: The pop cover has proved a remarkably imaginative and durable form, and this 60-year compilation tracks this pop alchemy at its finest and most intriguing through material sought from the Corporation's archive. Footage includes artists as diverse as the Moody Blues, Soft Cell, Alexandra Burke, Mariah Carey and UB40 scoring chart hits that are, in some cases, perhaps even better than the original.

programme.title: Secret Voices of Hollywood
programme.desc: Documentary revealing the secret world of the `ghost singers', who provided the vocals for some of Hollywood's biggest stars. The programme includes footage of the classic movies in which the songs appeared.(n)

programme.title: Seven Ages of Britain
programme.desc: David Dimbleby tells the story of the power struggle between the monarchy and the Church during the Middle Ages through treasures of the period, and reveals how the code of chivalry brought the two sides together. He also reassesses the cultural impact of Richard II's reign, and examines artefacts including the Mappa Mundi, Chaucer's Canterbury Tales and Britain's only preserved medieval crown.(n)

programme.title: Horizon
programme.sub-title: Horizon: Man on Mars - Mission to the Red Planet
programme.desc: The programme goes behind the scenes at Nasa to discover how the space agency is preparing for its most ambitious and daring mission yet - to land a manned craft on the surface of Mars. Reaching the planet would involve a journey of at least three years, and the film meets the scientists and engineers who are designing new rockets and spacesuits, as well as finding ways to help astronauts survive the perils of such a long voyage.(n)

programme.title: World News Today
programme.desc: The day's leading stories.(n)

programme.title: Top of the Pops: 1981
programme.desc: David `Kid' Jensen presents the December 3 edition, featuring Bad Manners, Soft Cell, Duran Duran, the Fun Boy Three, Godley and Creme, the Human League and Julio Iglesias.(n)

programme.title: Hidden Killers
programme.sub-title: Hidden Killers of the Edwardian Home
programme.desc: Part two of two. In the first five years of King Edward's reign there were 140,000 British patents issued, many using electricity. However, as historian Suzannah Lipscomb discovers, there was no regulation of this new energy, and cables were not insulated or appliances earthed to today's exacting standards. As a response to electrocutions and fires, asbestos was employed, but it would be some time until its own risks to health would be fully appreciated. Suzannah also looks at other dubious products associated with the era, such as the radioactive clock and arsenic soap.(n)

programme.title: MAKE! Craft Britain
programme.desc: Martha Kearney presents this celebration of the power of craft, following ordinary people as they discover the simple pleasure of learning a new skill. It's a tale of two workshops, as Yorkshire Moors embroiderer Marna Lunt welcomes a mixed group of student to her two-day course making lampshades, while on a Sunday morning in London, six students take up their scalpels to learn the art of paper cutting with teacher Christine Green.(n)

programme.title: A Very British Airline
programme.desc: Operations manager Kevin Mackenzie discusses the challenges of working in Heathrow - the world's most congested airport - and reveals how the airline handles the knock-on effects of passengers' actions - from panic attacks before take-off, to suspicious items discovered in luggage. At BA's flight centre, cadet pilots Joel Garabedian and Andy McLellan reach the final stages of their 18-month course in which they have been learning to fly passenger planes - each paying £84,000 for the privilege. Narrated by Stephen Mangan.(n)

programme.title: Natural World
programme.sub-title: Butterflies: A Very British Obsession - Natural World
programme.desc: Documentary capturing the beauty of butterflies close up, and revealing how they inspire the images of street artist Nick Walker and the performances of burlesque dancer Vicky Butterfly. The programme also raises the question of whether a passion for these elegant insects could help people preserve much-loved landscapes. Narrated by Imelda Staunton.(n)

programme.title: Arthur
programme.sub-title: Too Much of a Good Thing
programme.desc: Buster enlists Binky's help to keep him from gorging on delicious biscuits - will he manage to keep his self-control or will he crumble?.

programme.desc: Hoping to raise money to purchase a rare nut, Merl turns the stump into a hotel, but his only guest is Bigfoot - and he makes a big mess.

programme.desc: Toothless tries to settle a score with an old rival, but Hiccup has to stop him before the encounter turns fatal. Children's entertainment spin-off series from the movie How to Train Your Dragon, following the adventures of Hiccup and his dragon.

programme.title: Danger Mouse
programme.desc: Danger Mouse's attempts at gardening lead to a gigantic Welsh space plant taking over the world and an attack of intergalactic bees. Only Penfold's jam obsession can save the day!.

programme.desc: Henry VIII appears on a TV show, Charles Darwin sings about his theory of natural selection, and a pirate captain aims to be Alan Sugar's next Historical Apprentice.

programme.desc: Mo secures the lead role in the school play, but his delight is short-lived when his dad falls ill, and a devastating secret about his family history is revealed.

programme.title: Roy
programme.desc: A school board member pays a visit to assess Roy, who everyone fears will be kicked out of Ballyfermot because of his chequered history at the school. Comedy mixing live action and animation, about a cartoon boy trapped in the real world.

programme.title: Deadly 60
programme.desc: Steve's search for deadly animals takes him and the crew to South Africa to observe the great white shark, where he gets some fantastic views of the `king of the ocean' - and to demonstrate the team's hunting prowess, he has a special trick up his sleeve. Just as feared by many is the Cape Buffalo, known locally as the black-death. The presenter takes to the skies to track down a huge herd of this notoriously bad tempered bovine beast, before being charmed by the snake-stomping secretary bird.

Meanwhile over in accident and emergency, one patient has some grit in his head after a fall in the playground and another has injured his neck after performing a karate kick.

programme.title: Mary Portas: Secret Shopper
programme.desc: The retail guru returns for a third series and helps more brands and high-street chains improve the quality of service offered to their customers. In Surrey she works with the married owners of a struggling bridal boutique who are fighting for survival with mounting debts and piles of unsold stock. However, Mary is in for a big surprise when she meets the team, and faces the challenge of bringing in enough brides to turn their failing business around.

He also meets a woman who bought a 400-year-old Devon cottage, and has some solutions for turning this old house into a new home.

programme.desc: Documentary exploring the wealth gap in Britain via two charismatic but estranged siblings. Multi-millionaire Tory businessman Ivan Massow lives in a luxurious five-storey home in central London and goes hunting in his spare time. Cameras also follow his younger brother David, who ekes out a living as an odd-jobs man and lives in a white van on a lay-by, with no running water. In the hope it will narrow the gap between them, David and Ivan, who rarely see each other, spend four days living together.

With a new wave of super-rich moving in to London's poshest neighbourhoods, this documentary follows the lives of wealthy young Nigerians as they live what's dubbed `the shuttle life' between Lagos and London. They include Cuppy and Temi Otedola, heiresses to a $1.2billion fortune, and British-Nigerian multi-millionaire Alexander Amosu, who is preparing to launch a new business venture.

Other hopefuls include ex-Playboy bunny Jacqui, who is paired up with ex-stripper Ricky, and sensitive soul Steven, who is hoping to find someone who will get along with the most important lady in his life - his nan. programme.desc: Series pairing dogs from rescue centres around the UK with six people with disabilities. Aided by two of the country's top dog trainers, the aim is to transform the canine companions into disability helper dogs in 12 weeks. The first edition meets 26-year-old Emily, who has narcolepsy and cataplexy, meaning she can collapse up to 30 times a day, and desperately wants a dog to guard her when she passes out in the street. Meanwhile, Alan, who has Tourette's, wants a dog to support him during his tic attacks, which sometimes leave him hospitalised.

The force's Serious Crime team are investigating more sexual offences than ever before, ranging from attacks by strangers, to a surge in online grooming.

Creators Andy Hamilton and Guy Jenkin highlight the follies and foibles of contemporary politics, writing much of the show in the hours leading up to transmission. Starring Jack Dee, Claire Skinner. programme.desc: Kirstie Allsopp and Phil Spencer visit the Alcorn family in Peebles in the Scottish Borders. The family of four lives in a conservation area and while dad Dave loves their grey-stone Victorian villa for its picture-book charm, mum Amy despises its lack of practicality. With no off-road parking, no third bedroom and no downstairs bathroom - not to mention the small, draughty kitchen - she has quite a list. Would it be best to simply move on to one of the new properties picked out by Phil, or can Kirstie come up with a way of making their home work?.(n)

programme.title: Inside Birmingham Children's Hospital
programme.desc: New series. Documentary going behind the scenes of Birmingham Children's Hospital, exploring how the treatment affects the patients and their families. In the first episode, two fathers stand by while their sons undergo treatment, including a football coach trying to hold it together as his star player receives stitches after a serious tackle. Meanwhile, another dad prepares to go under the knife alongside his son, having offered to be a living donor for his liver transplant.
